topics.title: Agent vs Automation
topics.description: A quick, practical guide to Agent vs Automation.

hook.text: Agent vs Automation, explained like youâ€™re shipping it this week.

buildup.text: Make this your target condition: Use an agent only when decisions depend on context that changes.

discovery.text: If you only do one action today, do: Write the decision boundary in one sentence.

twist.text: A common self-own: Using an agent for a deterministic script task.

climax.text: Anchor the whole approach on this: Use an agent only when decisions depend on context that changes.

punchline.text: If itâ€™s a checklist, donâ€™t make it an agent.

quiz.question: When is an agent the right choice?
options: When the task is fully deterministic
When decisions depend on changing context

topics.title: The Observe â†’ Think â†’ Act Loop
topics.description: A quick win: understand The Observe â†’ Think â†’ Act Loop.

hook.text: Letâ€™s make The Observe â†’ Think â†’ Act Loop concrete.

buildup.text: Optimize for: Make the loop explicit so you can test each step.

discovery.text: Practical shortcut: Log inputs/outputs for each step of the loop.

twist.text: What not to do (even if itâ€™s tempting): Letting the model â€œimplicitlyâ€ decide without state.

climax.text: Make the loop explicit so you can test each step. â€” and youâ€™ll avoid most pain.

quiz.question: Whatâ€™s the main benefit of making the loop explicit?

topics.title: Problem Framing for Agents
topics.description: A short lesson to help you apply Problem Framing for Agents.

hook.text: If Problem Framing for Agents feels fuzzy, this will sharpen it.

buildup.text: Make this your target condition: Define the user outcome and the constraints before building.

discovery.text: Convert the idea into a checklist item: Write success as an observable output.

twist.text: The fastest way to regress: Starting with tools before a clear success definition.

climax.text: If youâ€™re forced to simplify, simplify to: Define the user outcome and the constraints before building.

punchline.text: If you canâ€™t measure it, you canâ€™t ship it.

topics.title: Failure Modes: Tool Errors vs Hallucinations

hook.text: The shortest useful explanation of Failure Modes: Tool Errors vs Hallucinations.

buildup.text: What youâ€™re really trying to achieve: Classify failures so fixes are targeted.

topics.title: Idempotency in Agent Actions
topics.description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Idempotency in Agent Actions.

hook.text: If Idempotency in Agent Actions feels fuzzy, this will sharpen it.

buildup.text: Treat this as the contract: Make actions safe to retry without causing duplicates.

discovery.text: Operational move: Use idempotency keys for side effects.

twist.text: The trapdoor here is: Charging, emailing, or writing twice on retry.

climax.text: If youâ€™re forced to simplify, simplify to: Make actions safe to retry without causing duplicates.

punchline.text: Retries are normal; duplicates are optional.

quiz.question: What prevents duplicate side effects on retries?

topics.title: Thin-Slice MVP for Agents
topics.description: One-minute skill: Thin-Slice MVP for Agents.

hook.text: Speed-run: Thin-Slice MVP for Agents.

buildup.text: What youâ€™re really trying to achieve: Ship the smallest loop that creates real user value.

discovery.text: Minimum viable practice: Start with one tool and one happy path.

twist.text: Donâ€™t let your system drift into this: Building â€œgeneral intelligenceâ€ before a working path.

climax.text: This is the â€œdo-not-forgetâ€ constraint: Ship the smallest loop that creates real user value.

topics.title: When Not to Use an Agent
topics.description: A quick win: understand When Not to Use an Agent.

hook.text: Speed-run: When Not to Use an Agent.

buildup.text: The main objective for When Not to Use an Agent is: Avoid agents when rules are stable and strict.

discovery.text: The simplest implementation step: Ask: can a deterministic function do this?

twist.text: The easy-to-miss pitfall: Using an agent as a fragile replacement for rules.

climax.text: This is the â€œdo-not-forgetâ€ constraint: Avoid agents when rules are stable and strict.

punchline.text: Use code for rules; agents for judgment.

quiz.question: When should you avoid an agent?
options: When rules are stable and strict

topics.title: Determinism vs Creativity (Temperature)
topics.description: Learn Determinism vs Creativity (Temperature) in one minute.

hook.text: One minute to de-risk Determinism vs Creativity (Temperature).

buildup.text: When in doubt, anchor on this: Use low variance for operations; isolate creativity.

discovery.text: Start here: Set temperature low for tool calls and structured tasks.

twist.text: The sneaky risk: Turning up temperature to â€œfixâ€ reliability.

climax.text: This is what â€œgoodâ€ reduces to: Use low variance for operations; isolate creativity.

punchline.text: Creativity is a mode, not a default.

quiz.question: Whatâ€™s the best default for tool-heavy tasks?

topics.title: Role + Goal + Constraints
topics.description: A quick, practical guide to Role + Goal + Constraints.

hook.text: Youâ€™re building Role + Goal + Constraints. Hereâ€™s the 60-second version.

buildup.text: Your north star: Constraints prevent drift and reduce surprises.

twist.text: The mistake that ruins it: Vague prompts that allow â€œhelpfulâ€ but wrong actions.

topics.title: Input Contracts (What the Agent Can Assume)
topics.description: A 60-second lesson on Input Contracts (What the Agent Can Assume).

hook.text: Input Contracts (What the Agent Can Assume), explained like youâ€™re shipping it this week.

buildup.text: The bar you want to clear: Define what inputs are required and what may be missing.

twist.text: The failure mode to anticipate: Assuming fields exist and failing unpredictably.

climax.text: Anchor the whole approach on this: Define what inputs are required and what may be missing.

topics.title: Structured Outputs with JSON Schema
topics.description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Structured Outputs with JSON Schema.

hook.text: Youâ€™re building Structured Outputs with JSON Schema. Hereâ€™s the 60-second version.

buildup.text: Treat this as the contract: Structure makes downstream code safe.

topics.title: Tool Selection: One Tool at a Time
topics.description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Tool Selection: One Tool at a Time.

hook.text: Hereâ€™s how Tool Selection: One Tool at a Time works when youâ€™re under pressure.

buildup.text: Reduce branching by selecting a single next tool. (thatâ€™s the whole game).

discovery.text: Make it real by doing this: Force a single â€œnext actionâ€ decision.

twist.text: Where teams usually slip: Trying multiple tools and merging guesses.

climax.text: Your final check before you ship: Reduce branching by selecting a single next tool.

topics.title: Error-Handling Prompts that Recover
topics.description: Learn Error-Handling Prompts that Recover in one minute.

hook.text: Speed-run: Error-Handling Prompts that Recover.

buildup.text: Keep the outcome simple: Recovery prompts should be specific and stateful.

discovery.text: If you only do one action today, do: Include error context + a changed strategy on retry.

twist.text: A common self-own: Repeating the same failing instruction.

climax.text: This is the â€œdo-not-forgetâ€ constraint: Recovery prompts should be specific and stateful.

topics.title: Few-Shot Examples for Tool Use
topics.description: Learn Few-Shot Examples for Tool Use in one minute.

hook.text: The shortest useful explanation of Few-Shot Examples for Tool Use.

buildup.text: What youâ€™re really trying to achieve: Examples anchor formatting and decision thresholds.

twist.text: This breaks reliability fast: Assuming the model will infer edge cases.

topics.title: Guarded Tool Use (Validate Before Act)
topics.description: A fast breakdown of Guarded Tool Use (Validate Before Act) for builders.

hook.text: The shortest useful explanation of Guarded Tool Use (Validate Before Act).

buildup.text: The point of Guarded Tool Use (Validate Before Act): Validate tool inputs before executing side effects.

discovery.text: This is the lever to pull: Run a validation step before side effects.

twist.text: Most â€œit didnâ€™t workâ€ stories start with: Letting the agent call tools with malformed params.

climax.text: If you want one rule that survives edge cases: Validate tool inputs before executing side effects.

topics.title: Tools vs Retrieval (When to RAG)
topics.description: One-minute skill: Tools vs Retrieval (When to RAG).

hook.text: Letâ€™s make Tools vs Retrieval (When to RAG) concrete.

buildup.text: A strong default here is: Use tools for actions; retrieval for knowledge.

discovery.text: A clean implementation path begins with: Ask: do we need facts or effects?

twist.text: The mistake that ruins it: Using RAG as a substitute for doing the action.

climax.text: Use tools for actions; retrieval for knowledge. â€” and youâ€™ll avoid most pain.

punchline.text: Facts come from retrieval; effects come from tools.

quiz.question: When should you prefer retrieval?
options: When you need an irreversible side effect
When you want to send emails
When you want to write to a DB

topics.title: Decomposition Strategies
topics.description: One-minute skill: Decomposition Strategies.

hook.text: The shortest useful explanation of Decomposition Strategies.

buildup.text: What youâ€™re really trying to achieve: Split work into steps with clear inputs/outputs.

climax.text: If you want one rule that survives edge cases: Split work into steps with clear inputs/outputs.

topics.title: Plan vs Execute (Two-Phase Thinking)
topics.description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Plan vs Execute (Two-Phase Thinking).

buildup.text: If you had to choose one outcome, choose: Separate planning from execution to reduce chaos.

topics.title: State Machines for Reliability
topics.description: A quick win: understand State Machines for Reliability.

hook.text: The shortest useful explanation of State Machines for Reliability.

buildup.text: The point of State Machines for Reliability: Explicit states prevent weird loops and dead ends.

twist.text: This is how it quietly breaks: Implicit state stored only in the modelâ€™s head.

topics.title: Retry Policies (What to Retry, What Not To)
topics.description: A short lesson to help you apply Retry Policies (What to Retry, What Not To).

hook.text: A quick win: Retry Policies (What to Retry, What Not To).

buildup.text: Define â€œgoodâ€ as: Retry only when retries can change the outcome.

discovery.text: Concrete technique: Retry read operations more than writes.

topics.title: Stop Conditions (When to Halt)

hook.text: The â€œdonâ€™t waste timeâ€ guide to Stop Conditions (When to Halt).

topics.title: Budgeting Tokens, Time, and Money

topics.title: Escalation to Humans (Human-in-the-Loop)
topics.description: A 60-second lesson on Escalation to Humans (Human-in-the-Loop).

hook.text: Youâ€™re building Escalation to Humans (Human-in-the-Loop). Hereâ€™s the 60-second version.

topics.title: Logging & Tracing (What to Record)

buildup.text: Optimize for: Trace decisions so you can reproduce failures.

discovery.text: To turn theory into results, do: Log prompts, tool calls, outputs, and decisions.

topics.title: Concurrency and Race Conditions

buildup.text: The point of Concurrency and Race Conditions: Concurrent actions need locks and idempotency.

twist.text: Donâ€™t let your system drift into this: Two agent runs writing the same record.

climax.text: This is the â€œdo-not-forgetâ€ constraint: Concurrent actions need locks and idempotency.

topics.title: Memory Types: Short vs Long
topics.description: One-minute skill: Memory Types: Short vs Long.

buildup.text: Success looks like this: Short-term context â‰  long-term memory.

topics.title: Evaluating Retrieval Quality

topics.title: Freshness vs Stability

topics.title: Human Review Calibration
